intro: Indigofera parviflora var. occidentalis, commonly known as the Western small-flowered indigo, is a flowering plant native to parts of Africa and the Middle East. It is a shrub or small tree that typically grows to a height of 1–3 meters, characterized by its trifoliate leaves and small, fragrant flowers. The plant produces pods that contain several seeds, and it is often found in arid or semi-arid environments. Its botanical significance lies in its role as a source of natural dyes and its use in traditional medicine.
